Mesites are not songbirds.

The claim that sexism has been a more important factor than the focus on temperate regions (which have fewer different species) was poorly substantiated. It's understandable that female ornithologists in recent years have been somewhat more likely than male ones to be interested in and focus on female bird song, but that doesn't prove that male ornithologists are sexist for being somewhat less interested on average, not does it by itself prove that the attention paid to female bird song before was inadequately little, let alone that this alleged insufficient attention was due to sexism. 'We' don't learn about female bird song 'only now'; the fact that female birds in the tropics sing was certainly already well-known in the 1950's, and Wikipedia cites a paper from the 50's on this topic, pointing out that 'these differences have been known for a long time'. And, as the cited 2003 paper states, 'female song seems rare in comparison [to male bird song]', and it adduces this fact, not sexism, as the reason for the long-lasting emphasis on male bird song. There seems to be an unfortunate tendency nowadays to see sexism and racism in all sorts of things without sufficient reasons for it.

So excited to see this topic because HEY WOW as it happens I am a woman who did my master's thesis on male vs. female singing of a tropical songbird!!! (The ‘i‘iwi or scarlet honeycreeper, Drepanis coccinea.) I am working on getting my research published, so stay tuned for that. I observed female singing, male-female duetting, and even female singing from the nest (which, as described in the video, is something females usually avoid, for good reason).

Just wanted to clarify something based on what I'm seeing in the comments about "OBVIOUSLY both sexes sing!!" No one's saying your chickens or your female parrots don't make noise... The research discussed here is not really about all noises made by all species of bird; when talking about "song", we're generally discussing birds from the suborder Passeri, a.k.a. the "songbirds". And "song" is generally understood as a special type of vocalization, a long, complex pattern of sounds with specific functions related to defending territory and/or attracting or keeping a mate; these complex vocalizations must be learned, similarly to human language. Birds of both sexes in all species also make vocalizations called "calls", which are generally shorter and less complex, are instinctive rather than learned, and have different functions.

It is the songs specifically that were assumed to be produced by male songbirds only. More and more we are discovering this is not the case, but in many species males do sing more than the females. Female vocal behavior has also been obscured by the amount of time females spend sitting silently on the nest (in species where this is primarily the female's job), during the period of time when most species are at their most territorial and the males are often exceptionally loud and visible. Interestingly, species where males and females have the same color plumage tend to have higher rates of female singing, but it is harder to tell the sexes apart and due to pre-existing biases, the singers were often assumed to be male.

Hope this provides some context. Thank you to SciShow for shining a spotlight on this subject... truly astounding how gender and geographic biases in the research led to such a long lasting misunderstanding of songbird behavior! More and more we're discovering how much variation and complexity exists in songbird behavior across the clade.

The classic "t-wit t-woo" of the tawny owl is often mistaken as just the call an individual makes, but it's actually a call and response between a female and male. The "t-wit" or "kee wick" call is from the female, and the "t-woo" or "churring" is a male's call.

transitive verb

When I was growing up in the suburbs of Chicago in the 70's, one of the most beautiful bird songs was that of cardinals. For many years I and my dad believed it was always the male singing because likely with his bright red color (as opposed to the majority gray of the female) was the easiest to spot way up in the trees.  Well one summer break from high school, we were thrilled to find a cardinal pair had built a nest in one corner of a wide awning that spread across the entire back of our enclosed porch. The male would regularly fly up into the opposite corner with food for the young.  I was quietly sitting on the porch, when he started the normal cardinal song (they are LOUD that close!).  I WAS STUNNED when I realized that song was actually performed by BOTH birds, alternating back and forth from opposite awning corners without missing a beat.
I always imagine birds having conversations amongst themselves.

I have parakeets as pets for almost 20 years now and I can tell you: The female is anything but quiet! She oftens mimicks the song of a male, either to make her partner jealous or to attract her partner (maybe this song is not the male searches a female song but a general non gendered "I want you by my side"-song used by both genders, yet he sings it all the time but she only sings this song when separated from her partner). She has a song to signal that she wants to be fed (it's a quiet song and she mimicks the regurgitation process used to get food out of the "belly" / goiter in order to feed another bird), she has a song for alarming her flock (a loud screetch), she has a song for dissatisfaction (when she wants to get inside the cage but can't because the entrance is blocked, she screams in a different way, it's a shorter screetch and less frequent), and everytime she goes for a fly around, she sing one scratchy "peep" while taking off etc. etc. I could go on. Females are orally as active as males.
Shout-out to all fellow ornithologists watching this video.
